revision.text:
[[File:The Bard (1774).jpeg|thumb|350px|''The Bard'', 1774, by [[Thomas Jones (artist)|Thomas Jones]] (1742–1803)]]
'''Welsh art''' refers to the traditions in the [[visual arts]] associated with [[Wales]] and [[Welsh people|its people]]. Most art found in, or connected with, Wales is essentially a regional variant of the forms and styles of the rest of the [[British Isles]], a very different situation from that of [[Welsh-language literature|Welsh literature]]. The term '''Art in Wales''' is often used in the absence of a clear sense of what "Welsh art" is, and to include the very large body of work, especially in [[landscape art]], produced by non-Welsh artists in Wales (or with a Welsh subject) since the later 18th century.<ref>Houseley explores the lack of a clear sense of "Welsh art" among contemporary artists and in Wales generally. See also Morgan, 371–372.</ref>
==Early history== [[File:British Museum gold thing 501594 fh000035.jpg|thumb|left|250px|The gold [[Mold Cape]], [[Bronze Age]], 1900–1600 BC]] [[Prehistoric Wales]] has left a number of significant finds: [[Kendrick's Cave]], [[Llandudno]] contained the [[Kendrick's Cave Decorated Horse Jaw]], "a decorated horse jaw which is not only the oldest known work of art from Wales but also unique among finds of [[Ice Age art]] from Europe", and is now in the [[British Museum]].<ref>Kendrick's Cave [https://www.britishmuseum.org/whats_on/touring_exhibitions_and_loans/sharing_the_treasures.aspx BM touring exhibition], [https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pe_prb/d/decorated_horse_jaw.aspx BM Highlights]</ref> In 2011 "faint scratchings of a speared reindeer" were found on a cave wall on the [[Gower peninsula]] which probably date to 12,000–14,000 BC, placing them among the earliest art found in Britain.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-west-wales-14272126 "Carving found in Gower cave could be oldest rock art"], BBC News online, South-West Wales, July 25, 2011</ref> The [[Mold Gold Cape]], also in the British Museum, and [[Banc Ty'nddôl sun-disc]] in the [[National Museum of Wales]] in [[Cardiff]] are likewise some of the most important British works of art from the [[Bronze Age]].
Many works of [[Iron Age]] [[Celtic art]] have been found in Wales.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1938/ | title=Celtic Art in Iron Age Wales| work=National Museum of Wales | author= | date=3 May 2007 | accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> and the finds from the period shortly before and after the Roman conquest, which reached Wales in AD 74-8, are especially significant. Pieces of metalwork from [[Llyn Cerrig Bach]] on [[Anglesey]] and other sites exemplify the final stages of [[La Tène style]] in the British Isles, and the [[Capel Garmon Firedog]] is a spectacular luxury piece of [[ironwork]], among the finest in Europe from the period.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1940/ | title=Stunning ironwork firedog uncovered in farmers field | work=National Museum of Wales | author= | date=4 May 2007 | accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> The [[Abergavenny Leopard Cup]], from the decades after the conquest, was found in 2003, and shows the presence of imported Roman luxury products in Wales, perhaps belonging to a soldier.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1951/ | title=Exquisite Roman treasure gives up its secrets | work=National Museum of Wales | author= | date=9 September 2007 | accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Ricemarch Psalter, Psalm 1.JPG|thumb|upright|right|The [[Ricemarch Psalter]], c. 1080, the start of Psalm 1:"Beatus vir..."]]
In the [[Early Medieval]] period, the [[Celtic Christianity]] of Wales participated in the [[Insular art]] of the British Isles and a number of [[illuminated manuscript]]s [[:Category:Illuminated manuscripts of Welsh origin|possibly of Welsh origin]] survive, of which the 8th century [[Hereford Gospels]] and [[Lichfield Gospels]] are the most notable. The 11th century [[Ricemarch Psalter]] (now in [[Dublin]]) is certainly Welsh, made in [[St David's]], and shows a late Insular style with unusual [[Viking]] influence, which is also seen in surviving pieces of metalwork of that period.
There are only fragments of the architecture of the period remaining. Unlike Irish [[high cross]] and [[Pictish stones]], early Welsh standing stones mainly employ geometric patterns and words, rather than figure representation; however, 10th century stones represent Christ and various saints. Little metalwork survives from the early period of the 5th–9th centuries in Wales. However, archaeological sites at Dinas Powys have revealed various artifacts such as [[penannular brooch]]es and other pieces of jewellery. Similar brooches have been discovered a site at Penycorddyn-mawr, near [[Abergele]], dating to the 8th century. During this period, the construction of [[Holy well]]s was also particularly commonplace in Wales.
Wales has rarely been very prosperous, and the most striking medieval architecture is military, often built by the Normans and English, especially the famous "[[Castles and Town Walls of King Edward in Gwynedd]]" and [[Beaumaris Castle]] in [[Anglesey]], recognised as [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]]s, [[Caerphilly Castle]] and the castles of the Welsh Prince Llywelyn the Great (such as [[Criccieth Castle]] and [[Dolbadarn Castle]]). There are a number of impressive [[List of abbeys and priories in Wales|monastic ruins]]; Welsh medieval churches are nearly all relatively modest, including the cathedrals. They very often had wall-paintings, panel altarpieces and much other religious art, but as in the rest of Britain very little has survived. [[Conwy]], an English garrison town with its medieval walls almost entirely intact, has a notable example of a 13th-century medieval stone town-house.
==The Renaissance in Wales== [[Peter Lord (art historian)|Peter Lord]] suggests that the Renaissance began in Wales around 1400.<ref>[http://www.southwales-eveningpost.co.uk/Art-historian-Peter-Lord-talks-new-book-Tradition/story-28873873-detail/story.html "Art historian Peter Lord talks The Tradition: A New History of Welsh Art: "It's a book for everyone" ", ''South Wales Evening Post'', 7 March 2016]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> Much of the art produced in this period was created in or for the church. [[Strata Florida Abbey]], for example, retains some of its medieval decorated tiles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cadw.gov.wales/daysout/strata-florida-abbey/?lang=en|title=Strata Florida Abbey|website=Cadw|access-date=17 May 2016}}</ref>
Despite the widespread destruction that took place during the Reformation and later the Commonwealth, a number of Welsh churches retain fragments of medieval [[stained glass]]. These include [[All Saints' Church, Gresford]], St Michael's Church, [[Caerwys]], St Mary's Church, [[Treuddyn]], St Elidan's Church, [[Llanelidan]], Church of St Mary & St Nicholas, [[Beaumaris]], St Gwyddelan's Church, [[Dolwyddelan]], and [[St David's Cathedral]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stainedglass.llgc.org.uk/main.php?func=nextpage&terms=&page=3|title=Medieval fragments|website=Stained Glass in Wales|access-date=17 May 2016}}</ref>
Fifteenth-century wall paintings have been uncovered in several Welsh church buildings, including St Cadoc's Church, [[Llancarfan]],<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-25214557 "Welsh church uncovers stunning medieval wall paintings", BBC News, 6 December 2013]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> [[St Illtyd's Church, Llantwit Major]] (which has a painting of [[Saint Christopher]] believed to date from around 1400),<ref>{{cite web|last=Llantwit Major Historical Society|title=St. Illtud's Church|url=http://www.llantwitmajorhistorysociety.co.uk/#/st-illtuds-church/4565870953|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> and [[St Teilo's Church, Llandeilo Tal-y-bont]]. The latter, during its reconstruction at [[St Fagans National History Museum]] during the 1990s, was found to contain wall paintings from several different periods, the earliest estimated as being from the first half of the fifteenth century.<ref>[http://www.buildingconservation.com/articles/medieval-wall-paintings/medieval-wall-paintings.htm Tom Organ, "Reconstructing Medieval Wall Paintings at St Teilo's", www.building.conservation.com]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> The wall paintings at Llancarfan are said to be "beyond compare in Wales".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/mind-blowing-medieval-art-unveiled-church-1888480|title='Mind-blowing’ medieval art is unveiled in church|author=Claire Miller|website=WalesOnline|date=28 March 2013|access-date=17 May 2016}}</ref> [[File:Miss Catherine Jones of Colomendy, near Mold - Richard Wilson.jpg|thumb|Rare portrait by [[Richard Wilson (painter)|Richard Wilson]], of his cousin Miss Catherine Jones of Colomendy, c. 1740]]
[[Plas Mawr]], a grand Elizabethan town-house in Conwy, built by [[Robert Wynn (MP)|Robert Wynn]], a local man who had been English ambassador to the [[Holy Roman Emperor]], has been extensively restored by [[Cadw]], both inside and out, to reflect its appearance when built in the second half of the sixteenth century.<ref>[http://cadw.gov.wales/daysout/plasmawr/?lang=en Cadw: Plas Mawr]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> Wales has numerous country houses from all periods after the Elizabethan, many still containing good portraits, but these were mostly painted in London or on the Continent.<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/galleries/faces/ "Faces of Wales" from the National Museum of Wales]</ref>
==Portraiture== Within Wales, [[portraiture]] is not common in the medieval and post-medieval periods, and the Welsh nobility and gentry usually went to London or other English centres to have their portraits painted; many of these remain in Welsh collections. [[Katheryn of Berain]],<ref>[https://www.museumwales.ac.uk/articles/2011-10-10/Katheryn-of-Berain/ National Museum of Wales: Katheryn of Berain]. Accessed 2 April 2016</ref> who claimed Tudor ancestry and earned the nickname "Mam Gymru" ("Mother of Wales") because of her network of relationships and descendants from four marriages, was painted by [[Adriaen van Cronenburgh]], a Dutch painter. The portrait was commissioned by her husband, Sir [[Richard Clough]], a merchant whose business caused the couple to settle briefly in Antwerp. Clough himself died before he could bring his wife to the new house he had built for her. Plas Clough, near his home town of Denbigh, includes a Flemish-style crow-stepped gable<ref>[http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-1064-plas-clough-denbigh#.VwFSNnarSM8 British Listed Buildings: Plas Clough, Denbigh]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref> The arms of the Holy Sepulchre (Clough had been made a [[Knight of the Holy Sepulchre]] earlier in his career) are painted on a plaque, but there are no surviving contemporary portraits of Clough himself.
[[William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke (died 1570)]], was one of the first Welsh nobles known to have collected paintings on a large scale. A portrait of him, dating from the 1560s, is held by the [[National Museum of Wales]]; it is attributed to [[Steven van Harwijck]], another Dutch artist.<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/art/online/?action=show_item&item=9 National Museum of Wales - William Herbert, 1st Earl of Pembroke]. Accessed 3 April 2016</ref>
Later, artisan painters such as [[William Roos]] and [[Hugh Hughes (painter)|Hugh Hughes]] began to seek portrait commissions.<ref>[https://www.llgc.org.uk/collections/learn-more/portraits/paintings-and-drawings/ National Library of Wales: Paintings and Drawings]. Accessed 18 April 2016</ref> Roos's 1835 portrait of preacher [[Christmas Evans]] is held by the [[National Museum of Wales]], as is Hughes' 1826 portrait of [[William Jenkins Rees]].<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/art/online/?action=show_works&item=379&type=artist Art Collections Online: Hugh Hughes]. National Museum of Wales. Accessed 18 April 2016</ref>
==Landscapes== [[File:Richard Wilson - Snowdon from Llyn Nantlle - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Snowdon]] from [[Llyn Nantlle Uchaf|Llyn Nantlle]]'', [[Richard Wilson (painter)|Richard Wilson]], c. 1766]] The best of the few Welsh artists of the 16th to 18th centuries tended to move elsewhere to work, but in the 18th century the dominance of [[landscape art]] in [[English art]] brought them motives to stay at home, and brought an influx of artists from outside to paint Welsh scenery, which was "discovered" by artists rather earlier than later landscape hotspots like the English [[Lake District]] and the [[Scottish Highlands]]. The Welsh painter [[Richard Wilson (painter)|Richard Wilson]] (1714–1782) is arguably the first major British landscapist, but rather more notable for Italian scenes than Welsh ones, although he did paint several on visits from London.
Wilson's pupil [[Thomas Jones (artist)|Thomas Jones]] (1742–1803), has a rather higher status today than in his own time, but mainly for his city scenes painted in Italy, though his ''The Bard'' (1774, Cardiff) is a classic work showing the emerging combination of the [[Celtic Revival]] and [[Romanticism]].<ref>[http://www.museum.ac.uk/en/2261/ NMOW, Welsh Artists of the 18th Century]. Though mainly known as a portraitist, [[John Downman]], born and died in Wales, is also noted for unusually realistic Italian townscape studies, and some Welsh landscapes.</ref> He returned to live in Wales on inheriting the family estate, but largely stopped painting. For most visiting artists the main attraction was dramatic mountain scenery, in the new taste for the [[Sublime (literary)|sublime]] partly stimulated by [[Edmund Burke]]'s ''[[A Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin of Our Ideas of the Sublime and Beautiful]]'' (1757), though some earlier works were painted in Wales in this strain.<ref>Rosenthal, 52–64</ref> Early works tended to see the Welsh mountains through the prism of the 17th century Italianate "wild" landscapes of [[Salvator Rosa]] and [[Gaspard Dughet]].<ref>Rosenthal, 56</ref> [[File:A Welsh Sunset River Landscape by Paul Sandby, RA.jpg|thumb|''A Welsh Sunset River Landscape'' by [[Paul Sandby]], showing rather better weather than most "sublime" landscapes]]
By the 1770s a number of guide books had been published, including Joseph Cradock's ''Letters from Snowdon'' (1770) and ''An Account of Some of the Most Romantic Parts of North Wales'' (1777). [[Thomas Pennant]] wrote ''Tour in Wales'' (1778) and ''Journey to [[Snowdon]]'' (1781/1783); though Welsh himself, Pennant had published a ''Tour in Scotland'' first, in 1769.<ref>Rosenthal, 61</ref> The first of a series of British tours by another leading promoter of the picturesque, [[William Gilpin (clergyman)|William Gilpin]], was ''Observations on the River Wye and several parts of South Wales, etc. relative chiefly to Picturesque Beauty; made in the summer of the year 1770'', but not published until 1782. [[Paul Sandby]] made his first recorded visit to [[Wales]] in 1770, later (1773) touring south Wales with Sir [[Joseph Banks]], resulting in the 1775 publication of ''XII Views in South Wales'' and a further 12 views the following year, part of a 48-plate series of [[aquatint]]s of Welsh views commissioned by Banks. This was an early example of many print series and illustrated books on Wales, often as valuable in terms of income to the artists as original works.
[[File:Joseph Wright of Derby. Landscape near Bedgellert, North Wales.c.1790-5.jpg|thumb|left|[[Joseph Wright of Derby]], ''Landscape near [[Beddgelert]], North Wales'', {{circa|1790–5}}]]
What might fifty years earlier have been merely regarded as inconvenience in travel could now been seen as an exciting adventure worth making the subject of a painting, as in [[Julius Caesar Ibbetson]]'s ''[[Phaeton (carriage)|Phaeton]] in a Thunderstorm'' (1798, now [[Temple Newsam]], Leeds) which shows a carriage struggling up a rough mountain road. It has a label on the back by the artist, recording that the incident occurred when he was travelling in Wales with the artist [[John "Warwick" Smith]] and the aristocrat [[Robert Fulke Greville]].<ref>Rosenthal, 52 & 54. [http://www.artchive.com/web_gallery/reproductions//235001-235500/235144/size1.jpg Image of ''[[Phaeton (carriage)|Phaeton]] in a Thunderstorm'']</ref> Ibbetson visited Wales often, and was also one of the first artists to record the Welsh [[Industrial Revolution]], and scenes of Welsh life.
North Wales tended to be more visited; the young [[watercolour]]ist [[John Sell Cotman]] embarked on his "first extended sketching tour" in 1800, starting from Bristol then following "a well-trodden path into the [[Wye Valley]], through [[Brecknockshire]] to [[Llandovery]] and north to [[Aberystwyth]]. In Conway he joined a group of artists gathered around the amateur [[Sir George Beaumont, 7th Baronet|Sir George Beaumont]]" perhaps meeting [[Thomas Girtin]] there, and continuing to [[Caernarfon|Caernarvon]] and [[Llangollen]]. A second trip followed in 1802; he continued to use motifs from his sketches throughout his career.<ref>Holcomb, 8</ref> Other artists often in Wales in this period included [[Francis Towne]], the brothers [[Cornelius Varley|Cornelius]] and [[John Varley (painter)|John Varley]] and John's pupils [[Copley Fielding]] and David Cox (for whose lifelong attachment to Wales see below). Even the caricaturist [[Thomas Rowlandson]] visited with [[Henry Wigstead]], a colleague, and they published ''Remarks on a Tour to North and South Wales, in the Year 1797'', an illustrated book.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/remarksonatourt00wigsgoog|title=Remarks on a Tour to North and South Wales: In the Year 1797|first=Henry|last=Wigstead|year=1800|publisher= W. Wigstead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite ODNB|id=24221 |title=Rowlandson, Thomas|first=John|last=Hayes}}</ref>
The French Revolutionary and [[Napoleonic War]]s made continental travel impossible for long periods, increasing the visitors to Wales and other parts of Britain. The young [[J. M. W. Turner]] made his first extended tour to South and mid-Wales in 1792, followed by North Wales in 1794, and a seven-week tour of Wales in 1798. He also visited Yorkshire and Scotland in the 1790s, but was unable to visit Europe until after the [[Treaty of Amiens]] in 1802, when he reached the [[Alps]]; he did not visit Italy until 1819.<ref>Wilton & Lyles, 326-7</ref> Many of his key early works drew on his Welsh travels, although they were painted back in London. His "first large classicising watercolour, a [[Claude Lorrain|Claudeian]] view of [[Caernarvon Castle]] at sunset" was exhibited at the [[Royal Academy]] in 1799, along with an oil of the same subject, and the next year he showed another view of the castle, this time with small foreground figures of "a [[bard]] singing to his followers of the destruction of Welsh civilization by the invading armies of [[Edward I of England|Edward I]]", another Claudeian formula that he was to repeat many times in major works for the rest of his career, and was arguably the first large "exhibition watercolour", reaching into the realm of [[history painting]].<ref>Wilton & Lyles,pp. 176 & 260. Respectively: Private Collection, Mellon Centre for British Art, Tate.</ref>
==Expansion== [[File:Cox - A WELSH FUNERAL.jpg|thumb|left|[[David Cox (artist)|David Cox]], ''A Welsh Funeral'', c. 1850]] It remained difficult for artists relying on the Welsh market to support themselves until well into the 20th century. The 1851 census records only 136 people describing their occupation as "artist" out of a population of 945,000, with a further 50 engaged in [[fine arts]]-related occupations such as [[engraving]].<ref>Harvey, John, ''The art of piety: the visual culture of Welsh Nonconformity'', p.75, University of Wales Press, 1995, {{ISBN|0-7083-1298-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7083-1298-8}}</ref> An [[Act of Parliament]] in 1857 provided for the establishment of a number of art schools throughout the United Kingdom, and the [[University of Wales Institute, Cardiff|Cardiff School of Art]] opened in 1865. Prior to that the annual report for 1855 of the government [[Science and Art Department]] shows a list of the larger type of Art School in many British cities, but none in Wales.<ref>1855, Table p. xxii</ref> Under a recently introduced new system "Local Schools of Art" had been established in 1853 in [[Llanelly]] and [[Merthyr]], but had already closed; those in [[Swansea]] and [[Carmarthen]] continued, and [[Flint, Flintshire|Flint]] had applied to establish a school. There were "Drawing Schools" in [[Aberdare]] and [[Bangor, Gwynedd|Bangor]], but apparently nothing at all in Cardiff.<ref>1855, Appendix A, pp. 21–26</ref> However all these pre-1857 schools, except perhaps Swansea, were mainly teaching school age children, usually in their normal schools, and training in industrial design or teacher-training under the elementary stages of the "[[South Kensington system]]".<ref>1855, pp. xxii–xxx</ref> [[File:Mansel Lewis - Snowdonia.jpg|thumb|Mansel Lewis, ''[[Snowdonia]]'']]
Graduates of the new fine arts Welsh colleges still very often had to leave Wales to work. Established artists continued to move in the opposite direction, at least for the summer. [[David Cox (artist)|David Cox]] was an English 19th century landscapist who spent much time in Wales, for many years spending the summer based in [[Betws-y-Coed]], a popular centre for artists, including the English [[Henry Clarence Whaite]] and the German [[Hubert von Herkomer]], one of whose wives was Welsh. Landscape continued to be the main focus, although the Welsh artist [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/Category:Mansel_Lewis Charles William Mansel Lewis] was among those who painted common working people, with varying measures of realism or picturesqueness. The "Betws-y-Coed artist's colony" was one of the groups forming the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art]] in 1881; this was always a group for exhibiting rather than a teaching institution, based in Conwy, until 1994 in Plas Mawr (see above).[[File:Walescw.jpg|thumb|upright|left|''Deffroad Cymru, the Awakening of Wales'' (1911), by [[Christopher Williams (Welsh artist)|Christopher Williams]] (1873–1934)]] <ref>[http://www.rcaconwy.org/our_history-5.aspx Royal Cambrian Academy]</ref> The sculptors [[John Evan Thomas (Welsh sculptor)|John Evan Thomas]] (1810–1873) and Sir William [[Goscombe John]] (1860–1952) made many works for Welsh commissions, although they had settled in London. Even [[Christopher Williams (Welsh artist)|Christopher Williams]] (1873–1934), whose subjects were mostly resolutely Welsh, was based in London. [[Thomas E. Stephens]] (1886–1966) and [[Andrew Vicari]] (b. 1938) had very successful careers as portraitists based respectively in the United States and France. Sir [[Frank Brangwyn]] was Welsh by origin, but spent little time in Wales.
Perhaps the most famous Welsh-born painters were [[Augustus John]] and his sister [[Gwen John]], though they mostly lived in London and Paris; however the landscapists Sir [[Kyffin Williams]] (1918–2006) and [[Peter Prendergast (artist)|Peter Prendergast]] (1946–2007) remained living in Wales for most of their lives, though well in touch with the wider art world. [[Ceri Richards]] was very engaged in the Welsh art scene as a teacher in Cardiff, and even after moving to London; he was a figurative painter in international styles including [[Surrealism]]. Various artists have moved to Wales, usually the countryside, though paintings of [[Cardiff]] of around 1893–97 by the American artist [[Lionel Walden]] are in museums in Cardiff and Paris.<ref>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/art/online/?action=show_item&item=1860 National Museum of Wales, Walden]</ref> These included [[Eric Gill]], whose colony included for his most artistically productive period (1924–1927) the London-born Welshman [[David Jones (poet)|David Jones]], and the sculptor [[Jonah Jones (sculptor)|Jonah Jones]]. [[The Kardomah Gang]] was an intellectual circle centred on the poet [[Dylan Thomas]] and poet and artist [[Vernon Watkins]] in Swansea, which also included the painter [[Alfred Janes]]; the eponymous cafe was destroyed by a German bomb in 1941.
The situation gradually improved after World War II, with the appearance of new art groups. ''The South Wales Group'' was established in 1948 (and continues today as [[The Welsh Group]] with membership from across Wales).<ref name="The Welsh Group">[http://www.thewelshgroup-art.com/#!about-amdanom/ciaa] The Welsh Group website. Retrieved 2015-01-20.</ref><ref name="60 creative years">Karen Price, [http://www.walesonline.co.uk/showbiz-and-lifestyle/news/2008/11/21/art-group-marking-60-creative-years-91466-22306900/ "Art group marking 60 creative years"], WalesOnline, 21 November 2008. Retrieved 2013-04-23.</ref><ref name="Planet Mapping">David Moore, [http://www.planetmagazine.org.uk/html/newsite/onlinedetails/The_Welsh_Group.html Mapping the Welsh Group at Sixty: The Exhibition], Planet Online. Retrieved 2013-04-23.</ref><ref>http://www.llgc.org.uk/index.php?id=1513&no_cache=1&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1386&cHash=8e57b2d7d9bdf30aa36c37d7d06e3731</ref><ref>http://welshgroup.co.uk/WGrpIndex.htm</ref> The group’s initial conception was in response to the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art|Royal Cambrian Academy’s]] relatively weak representation from [[south Wales]] at the time. In 1956 when the ''South Wales Group'' failed to become a southern Academy, the [[56 Group Wales]] also emerged,<ref name="50 years">Peter Wakelin, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aXYySHER7x8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=50+Years+of+the+Welsh+Group.+Peter+Wakelin&hl=en&sa=X&ei=IF8vUcqiBoe50QWNxYDQCA&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA “50 years of the Welsh Group"], National Museum of Wales (1999), {{ISBN|0-7200-0472-1}}</ref> with the aim of promoting modern Welsh art beyond Wales' borders.<ref>Peter Wakelin, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aXYySHER7x8C&pg=PA43&dq=Arthur+Giardelli&hl=en&sa=X&ei=xFpTT5i_EKOA0AXpzLDpCw&ved=0CF8QuwUwCA#v=onepage&q=Arthur%20Giardelli&f=false "50 years of the Welsh Group"], National Museum of Wales (1999), pp. 39–43, {{ISBN|0-7200-0472-1}}</ref> Also in the industrial valleys the [[Dowlais]] Settlement, delivering art classes and activities was established in the 1940s by artists including [[Heinz Koppel]] and [[Arthur Giardelli]] and the [[Rhondda Group]] was formed in the 1950s, a loose group of art students whose most notable member was [[Ernest Zobole]], whose expressionist work was deeply rooted in the juxtaposition of the industrialised buildings of the valleys set against the green hills that surround them.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/arts/sites/ernest-zobole/ | title=Walesart, Ernest Zobole | work=BBC Wales online | author= | date= | accessdate=23 October 2010}}</ref> In the 1970s, Paul Davies formed [[Beca (artist group)|Beca]], a radical Welsh group whose founding was in part a reaction to the drowning of [[Capel Celyn]].<ref name="ArtinWales">{{cite web | url=http://www.artcornwall.org/features/Iwan_Bala_Art_in_Wales.htm | title=Art in Wales: Politics of Engagement or Engagement with Politics? | work=artcornwall.org | author= | date= | accessdate=23 October 2010}}</ref> Beca used a mixture of artistic expression, including installation, painting, sculpture and performance, engaging with language, environmental and land rights issues.<ref>Davies (2008) p. 56</ref>
==Decorative arts== [[File:Dynevor Service (Plate) LACMA 55.101.4b.jpg|thumb|Swansea porcelain plate, c. 1817]] South Wales had several notable potteries in the late 18th and 19th centuries, beginning with the [[Cambrian Pottery]] (1764–1870, also known as "[[Swansea]] pottery") and including [[Nantgarw Pottery]] near Cardiff, which was in operation from 1813 to 1822 making fine [[porcelain]], and then utilitarian pottery until 1920. [[Portmeirion Pottery]] (from 1961) has never in fact been made in Wales.
Despite the fact that considerable quantities of [[silver]] (in association with [[lead]]), and much smaller amounts of [[gold]], were mined in Wales, there was little silversmithing in Wales in the Early Modern period. It did not help that the Crown gave itself ownership of mines of [[precious metal]]s, which were largely used for minting currency, some of which was marked with the [[Prince of Wales's feathers]] to show its origin. The Welsh gentry mostly had their silver made in English cities.
==Contemporary Welsh Art== Today Welsh and Wales based artists, including members of [[The Welsh Group]], the [[56 Group Wales]], the [[Royal Cambrian Academy of Art|Royal Cambrian Academy]] and artists not affiliated with any particular group, provide a varied [[contemporary art|contemporary]] tapestry of art across Wales. From the [[Abstract Art]] of Brendan Stuart Burns<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arts.wales/arts-in-wales/inspire/make/creative-wales/creative-wales-archive/awards-2013-14/brendan-stuart-burns |title=Brendan Stuart Burns |work=Arts Council in Wales |accessdate=14 April 2016}}</ref> or [[Martyn Jones (painter)|Martyn Jones]], to the expressive, modern figurative art of [[Shani Rhys James]], [[Clive Hicks-Jenkins]] or Rhŷn Williams, from the politically charged work of [[Iwan Bala]] or [[Ivor Davies (artist)|Ivor Davies]] to the [[Pop Art]] of [[Ken Elias]]. The contemporary art of Wales is noted perhaps more for its variety, rather than having a single set agenda. However, perhaps due to market forces or the inspirational shapes and changing light, the Welsh landscape is still particularly well represented in commercial galleries throughout Wales and beyond, either through the expressive, almost abstract, techniques used by artists like [[David Tress]] or the more traditional approaches used by others like [[Rob Piercy]].
==Conceptual art in Wales== [[File:B for Defiance by David Garner.jpg|thumb|left|150px|B for Defiance by David Garner]] Conceptual art is represented in Wales with a number of successful artists including [[Bedwyr Williams]] and [[David Garner (artist)|David Garner]] together with performance artists like the group TRACE,<ref>http://huwdavidjones.wordpress.com/2008/08/01/trace-displaced-gwaithwork/</ref><ref>http://www.performance-wales.org/events/tracedisplaced.html</ref> creating and showing work in Wales and beyond. A number of Welsh galleries focus on conceptual art, with the most significant perhaps being ''Mostyn''<ref>http://www.mostyn.org/</ref> in north Wales and ''[[Chapter Arts Centre]]'' and ''g|39''<ref>http://www.g39.org/</ref> in south Wales. The Gold Medal at '[[Y Lle Celf]]' in the [[National Eisteddfod of Wales]] has seen a notable trend towards more conceptual approaches over the last ten or so years, with [[Installation art|Installation work]] being the usual focal point.<ref>http://huwdavidjones.wordpress.com/2008/08/01/art-at-the-national-eisteddfod-of-wales/</ref> The 2003 development of the Artes Mundi prize and Wales's presence at the Venice Biennale has strengthened the country's international reputation for [[Conceptual art|Conceptual]] and [[Installation art]].
===Artes Mundi and Wales at the Venice Biennale===
Since 2003 the [[Artes Mundi]] biennial art prize has been held at the [[National Museum Cardiff]]. The prize is the biggest art prize in the [[United Kingdom]] with £40,000 for each year’s winner.<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/wales/posts/artes-mundi-5-at-national-museum-cardiff</ref> Though the prize has included artists who use traditional media, like paint, this is usually only part of their practice, with the focus being very much on conceptual approaches. Though the exhibition takes place in Cardiff, the focus is on international artists,<ref>http://www.artesmundi.org/</ref><ref>http://www.walesartsreview.org/artes-mundi-5-national-museum-cardiff/</ref><ref>http://www.walesonline.co.uk/all-about/artes%20mundi</ref> with Tim Davies from Pembrokeshire <ref>http://www.artesmundi.org/en/exhibitions-prizes/artes-mundi-one</ref> and [[Cornwall]] born Sue Williams<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/arts/sites/sue-williams/</ref> being the only Wales based artists to have featured to date.
Also adding to the international flavour in 2003, Wales took part in the [[Venice Biennale]] with its own pavilion<ref>http://www.artscouncilofwales.org.uk/artsinwales/venice</ref><ref>http://venicebiennale.britishcouncil.org/uk-in-venice</ref> and has continued to do so ever since, showing work by conceptual Welsh artists including [[John Cale]] in 2009,<ref>http://venicebiennale.britishcouncil.org/people/reference/john-cale</ref> Tim Davies in 2011<ref>http://www.wai.org.uk/news/2235</ref> and [[Bedwyr Williams]] in 2013.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-22736582</ref>
{{clear}}
==Welsh artists== {{Culture of Wales}} A selected list; for many more, see [[:Category:Welsh artists]] or [[List of Welsh artists]] *[[Barry Flanagan]], (1941–2009), sculptor *[[John Gibson (sculptor)|John Gibson]], (1790–1866), sculptor *[[Nina Hamnett]] (1890–1956), painter *[[Augustus John]] (1878–1961), painter *[[Gwen John]] (1876–1939), painter *Sir William [[Goscombe John]] (1860–1952), sculptor *[[David Jones (poet)|David Jones]] (1895–1974), artist and poet *[[Thomas Jones (artist)|Thomas Jones]] (1742–1803), painter *[[Ceri Richards]] (1903–1971), painter *[[Andrew Vicari]] (born 1938), painter *[[Kyffin Williams]] (1918–2006), painter *[[Richard Wilson (painter)|Richard Wilson]] (1714–1782), painter
==See also== * [[Architecture of Wales]] * [[Arts Council of Wales]] * [[National Museum of Wales]] * [[Welsh Artist of the Year]] * [[Art in Cardiff]] * [[Art of the United Kingdom]] * [[Celtic art]] * [[Irish art]] * [[Scottish art]] * [[:Category:Welsh Eisteddfod Gold Medal winners|Welsh Eisteddfod Gold Medal winners]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==References== *Adele M Holcomb, ''John Sell Cotman'', 1978, British Museum Publications {{ISBN|0714180041}}/5x *Housley, William. ''Artists, Wales, Narrative and Devolution'', in ''Devolution and identity'', eds John Wilson, Karyn Stapleton, 2006, Ashgate Publishing, {{ISBN|0-7546-4479-0}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7546-4479-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=OC81QwhbyEoC&pg=PA85&dq=Welsh+art&as_brr=3&cd=1#v=onepage&q=Welsh%20art&f=false google books] *[[Morgan, Kenneth O.]], ''Rebirth of a Nation: Wales 1880–1980'', Volume 6 of History of Wales, Oxford University Press, 1982, {{ISBN|0-19-821760-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-19-821760-2}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=asSr71jWDIEC&pg=PA372&dq=%22Welsh+art%22+-Barron&lr=&cd=21#v=onepage&q=%22Welsh%20art%22%20-Barron&f=false google books] * Rosenthal, Michael, ''British Landscape Painting'', 1982, Phaidon Press, London *Wakelin, Peter, ''Creu cymuned o arlunwyr: 50 mlynedd o'r Grŵp Cymreig''/''Creating an Art Community, 50 Years of the Welsh Group'', National Museum of Wales, 1999, {{ISBN|0-7200-0472-1}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7200-0472-4}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=aXYySHER7x8C&pg=PA86&dq=%22Welsh+painting%22&as_brr=3&cd=3#v=onepage&q=%22Welsh%20painting%22&f=false google books] *"1855" – ''Report of the Department of Science and Art of the Committee of Council on Education: with appendix : presented to both Houses of Parliament by command of Her Majesty'', Department of Science and Art, [[H.M.S.O.]], 1855, [https://books.google.com/books?id=lPI9AAAAcAAJ&dq=Swansea+School+of+Art&as_brr=3&source=gbs_navlinks_s online text] * Andrew Wilton & Anne Lyles, The Great Age of British Watercolours (1750–1880), 1993, Prestel, {{ISBN|3-7913-1254-5}}
==Further reading== *Lord, Peter, ''Imaging the nation'', Volume 2 of Visual culture of Wales, University of Wales Press, 2000, {{ISBN|0-7083-1587-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7083-1587-3}} *Lord, Peter, ''The Betws y Coed Artists' Colony: Clarence Whaite and the Welsh Art World'', 2009, Coast and Country Productions Ltd, {{ISBN|1-907163-06-9}} *Rowan, Eric, ''Art in Wales: an illustrated history, 1850–1980'', Welsh Arts Council, University of Wales Press, 1985, Alan Torjussen, "A Wales Art Collection - Casgliad Celf Cymru", bilingual art education project for schools and adults (A3 cards, A6 cards, CD Rom), Genesis 2014, {{ISBN|978-0-9535202-7-5}} etc.
Alan Torjussen, "Teaching Art in Wales - Dysgu Celf yng Nghymru", bilingual art education project for schools and adults (A3 cards, teachers book, videos), Genesis & University of Wales Press 1997

revision.text:
{{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = You Deserve a Drink | image = You Deserve a Drink (book).jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = [[Mamrie Hart]] | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = | set_in = | published = | publisher = [[Plume (publisher)|Plume]] | publisher2 = | pub_date = May 26, 2015 | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | awards = | isbn = 9780142181676 | oclc = 2092782789 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = http://www.ydadbook.com/ }}
'''''You Deserve a Drink: Boozy Misadventures and Tales of Debauchery'''''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hallemann|first1=Caroline|title=YouTube Star Mamrie Hart Talks Airplane Cocktails, Travel Beauty Products, and Her New Book, You Deserve a Drink|url=http://www.travelandleisure.com/articles/mamrie-hart-interview|publisher=Travel + Leisure|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref> is a memoir and cookbook written by [[YouTube personality]] and comedian [[Mamrie Hart]]. The book was published by [[Plume (publisher)|Plume]] and released on May 26, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Putnam|first1=Lindsay|title=Mamrie Hart is YouTube’s raunchiest — and booziest — star|url=https://nypost.com/2015/05/26/mamrie-hart-is-youtubes-raunchiest-and-booziest-star/|publisher=New York Daily News|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Library of Congress LCCN Permalink for 2015004927|url=http://lccn.loc.gov/2015004927|website=lccn.loc.gov|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref>
==Plot== The book details humorous anecdotes and stories of Hart's life, with a cocktail recipe accompanying each chapter.<ref>{{cite web|title=YouTube star and author Mamrie Hart made us a custom cocktail|url=http://fusion.net/video/139914/youtube-star-and-author-mamrie-hart-made-us-a-custom-cocktail/|publisher=Fusion|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref>
==Critical reception== ''You Deserve a Drink'' was generally well-received by reviewers. Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', actor and comedian [[Michael Ian Black]] stated that "Hart is a pull-no-punches comedian with a talent for self-deprecation in the guise of self-aggrandizement, a winning formula."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Black|first1=Michael|title=Humor|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/31/books/review/humor.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref>
Colleen Stinchcombe, writer for [[SheKnows Media|She Knows]] said that "She is undeniably a funny lady, and her humor translates beautifully — even more powerfully, I'd argue — to the page. Her jokes have more time to build, her punchlines land harder. She's created an entirely hilarious read that will delight her current fans by giving them a pitcher-sized serving of her normally shot-sized jokes and entice new readers who have enjoyed recent books by other humor heavy-hitters."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Stinchcombe|first1=Colleen|title=Mamrie Hart's new memoir is a hilarious lesson in radical self-acceptance|url=http://www.sheknows.com/entertainment/articles/1084050/you-deserve-a-drink-is-a-book-about-radical-self-acceptance|publisher=She Knows|accessdate=6 June 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
